In this autoimmune disease, the <fact5>antibodies</fact5> typically target components of the <fact4>epidermal basement membrane</fact4>, specifically the hemidesmosomes, which are critical for the adhesion of the epidermis to the dermis. Therefore, the most likely cell junction to which the <fact5>antibodies</fact5> bind is {D}.

question:
A 45-year-old homeless man comes to the emergency department because of progressive neck pain for 3 days. He also reports headaches and numbness in both hands. Over the past 4 months, he has had intermittent lower back pain after waking up. The back pain improves with movement. He also has recurrent episodes of gout in the metatarsophalangeal joint of his right big toe. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks four beers daily. The patient is a known user of intravenous heroin. He appears acutely ill. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. There are several track marks on both forearms. Examination of the neck shows warmth, erythema, and limited range of motion. Gentle palpation over the midcervical spinal processes causes severe pain. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11 g/dL
Leukocyte count 14,200/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 77%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 2%
Platelet count 278,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 54 mm/h
Blood cultures are pending. An x-ray of the cervical spine shows no abnormalities. An MRI of the spine shows signs of inflammation. A bone biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?"
A) Lumbar puncture
B) Intravenous ciprofloxacin and vancomycin therapy
C) Surgical debridement
D) Oral indomethacin therapy
E) Bone scintigraphy
"
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>45-year-old homeless man</fact1> comes to the emergency department because of <fact2>progressive neck pain for 3 days</fact2>. He also reports <fact3>headaches and numbness in both hands</fact3>. Over the past <fact4>4 months</fact4>, he has had <fact5>intermittent lower back pain after waking up</fact5>. The <fact6>back pain improves with movement</fact6>. He also has <fact7>recurrent episodes of gout in the metatarsophalangeal joint of his right big toe</fact7>. He has <fact8>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years</fact8> and drinks <fact9>four beers daily</fact9>. The patient is a known user of <fact10>intravenous heroin</fact10>. He appears <fact11>acutely ill</fact11>. His <fact12>temperature is 39°C (102.2°F)</fact12>, <fact13>pulse is 110/min</fact13>, and <fact14>blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg</fact14>. There are several <fact15>track marks on both forearms</fact15>. Examination of the neck shows <fact16>warmth, erythema, and limited range of motion</fact16>. Gentle palpation over the <fact17>midcervical spinal processes causes severe pain</fact17>. Laboratory studies show: <fact18>Leukocyte count 14,200/mm3</fact18>, <fact19>Segmented neutrophils 77%</fact19>, and <fact20>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 54 mm/h</fact20>. <fact21>Blood cultures are pending</fact21>. An <fact22>x-ray of the cervical spine shows no abnormalities</fact22>. An <fact23>MRI of the spine shows signs of inflammation</fact23>. A <fact24>bone biopsy confirms the diagnosis</fact24>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer:
Given the patient's presentation of <fact2>progressive neck pain for 3 days</fact2>, <fact3>headaches and numbness in both hands</fact3>, along with <fact16>warmth, erythema, and limited range of motion</fact16> in the neck and <fact17>severe pain upon palpation of the midcervical spinal processes</fact17>, there is a strong indication of a spinal infection. The elevated <fact18>leukocyte count</fact18> and <fact20>erythrocyte sedimentation rate</fact20> further support the presence of an infectious process. The <fact23>MRI findings of spinal inflammation</fact23> and the confirmation of the diagnosis through a <fact24>bone biopsy</fact24> solidify the diagnosis of a spinal infection. Considering the patient's history of <fact10>intravenous heroin use</fact10> and the presence of <fact15>track marks on both forearms</fact15>, there is a high likelihood that the infection is caused by a bacterial pathogen, such as Staphylococcus aureus. Given these factors, the most appropriate next step in management would be to initiate antibiotic therapy that covers methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and other likely pathogens. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 45-year-old African-American male presents to the family medicine physician to assess the status of his diabetes. After reviewing the laboratory tests, the physician decides to write the patient a prescription for miglitol and states that it must be taken with the first bite of the meal. Which of the following bonds will no longer be cleaved when the patient takes miglitol?
A) Phosphodiester bonds
B) Glycosidic bonds
C) Peptide bonds
D) Cystine bonds
E) Hydrogen bonds
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old African-American male</fact1> presents to the family medicine physician to assess the status of his <fact2>diabetes</fact2>. After reviewing the laboratory tests, the physician decides to write the patient a prescription for <fact3>miglitol</fact3> and states that it must be taken with the <fact4>first bite of the meal</fact4>. Which of the following bonds will no longer be cleaved when the patient takes <fact3>miglitol</fact3>?

Answer: 
Considering the patient has been prescribed <fact3>miglitol</fact3> for his <fact2>diabetes</fact2> and is instructed to take it with the <fact4>first bite of the meal</fact4>, it indicates that <fact3>miglitol</fact3> is an oral anti-diabetic drug that works by inhibiting intestinal enzymes. Specifically, <fact3>miglitol</fact3> is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, which means it blocks the enzyme responsible for breaking down carbohydrates into simple sugars. This enzyme breaks <fact5>glycosidic bonds</fact5> in carbohydrates. Therefore, when the patient takes <fact3>miglitol</fact3>, the <fact5>glycosidic bonds</fact5> will no longer be cleaved, slowing down carbohydrate absorption and helping to manage <fact2>diabetes</fact2>. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of genital lesions. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules over the vulva. The lesions turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
A) Condoms
B) Anti-HIV prophylaxis
C) Spermicidal foam
D) Famciclovir therapy
E) Vaccination
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>15-year-old girl</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>2-week history of genital lesions</fact2>. She has no history of serious illness. She is <fact3>sexually active with 2 male partners</fact3> and uses <fact4>condoms inconsistently</fact4>. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows <fact5>multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules over the vulva</fact5>. The <fact6>lesions turn white on application of 3% acetic acid</fact6>. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation of <fact5>multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules over the vulva</fact5> that <fact6>turn white on application of 3% acetic acid</fact6>, these findings are indicative of human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, which is a common cause of genital warts. Given that she is <fact3>sexually active with 2 male partners</fact3> and uses <fact4>condoms inconsistently</fact4>, the most effective preventive measure against HPV infection would be vaccination. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 60-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of increasing difficulty in breathing with a productive cough. He reports having shortness of breath over the last 6 months, but he has felt worse since he contracted a cold that has been traveling around his office. Today, he reports body aches, headache, and fever along with this chronic cough. His past medical history is significant for prediabetes, which he controls with exercise and diet. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history. His blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse rate is 90/min, temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds bilateral, a barrel-shaped chest, and measured breathing through pursed lips. A chest X-ray reveals a flattened diaphragm and no signs of consolidation. Pulmonary function testing reveals FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%. Arterial blood gases (ABG) of this patient are most likely to reveal which of the following?
A) Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis
B) Primary respiratory acidosis
C) Primary respiratory alkalosis
D) Compensatory respiratory acidosis
E) Anion gap metabolic acidosis with respiratory alkalosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>60-year-old man</fact1> presents with a <fact2>2-day history of increasing difficulty in breathing</fact2> with a productive cough. He reports having <fact3>shortness of breath over the last 6 months</fact3>, but he has felt worse since he contracted a cold that has been traveling around his office. Today, he reports <fact4>body aches, headache, and fever</fact4> along with this chronic cough. His past medical history is significant for <fact5>prediabetes</fact5>, which he controls with exercise and diet. He has a <fact6>30-pack-year smoking history</fact6>. His <fact7>blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse rate is 90/min</fact8>, <fact9>temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F)</fact9>, and <fact10>respiratory rate is 18/min</fact10>. Physical examination reveals <fact11>diminished breath sounds bilateral</fact11>, a <fact12>barrel-shaped chest</fact12>, and measured breathing through pursed lips. A <fact13>chest X-ray reveals a flattened diaphragm</fact13> and no signs of consolidation. <fact14>Pulmonary function testing reveals FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%</fact14>. Arterial blood gases (ABG) of this patient are most likely to reveal which of the following?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact6>30-pack-year smoking history</fact6> and the presence of a <fact12>barrel-shaped chest</fact12> and <fact13>flattened diaphragm on chest X-ray</fact13>, it is likely that the patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The <fact14>FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%</fact14> from pulmonary function testing further supports this diagnosis, indicating an obstructive pattern. In COPD, there is often a degree of carbon dioxide retention leading to a primary respiratory acidosis. Therefore, the most likely finding on arterial blood gases (ABG) would be a primary respiratory acidosis. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 5-year-old male is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of a painful mouth/gums, and vesicular lesions on the lips and buccal mucosa for the past 4 days. The patient has not been able to eat or drink due to the pain and has been irritable. The patient also reports muscle aches. His vital signs are as follows: T 39.1, HR 110, BP 90/62, RR 18, SpO2 99%. Physical examination is significant for vesicular lesions noted on the tongue, gingiva, and lips, with some vesicles having ruptured and ulcerated, as well as palpable cervical and submandibular lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism in this patient's presentation?
A) CMV
B) EBV
C) HIV
D) HSV-1
E) HSV-2
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>5-year-old male</fact1> is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of <fact2>painful mouth/gums, and vesicular lesions on the lips and buccal mucosa</fact2> for the past <fact3>4 days</fact3>. The patient has not been able to <fact4>eat or drink due to the pain</fact4> and has been <fact5>irritable</fact5>. The patient also reports <fact6>muscle aches</fact6>. His vital signs are as follows: <fact7>T 39.1, HR 110, BP 90/62, RR 18, SpO2 99%</fact7>. Physical examination is significant for <fact8>vesicular lesions noted on the tongue, gingiva, and lips, with some vesicles having ruptured and ulcerated</fact8>, as well as <fact9>palpable cervical and submandibular lymphadenopathy</fact9>. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism in this patient's presentation?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, particularly the <fact2>painful mouth/gums, and vesicular lesions on the lips and buccal mucosa</fact2>, along with the presence of <fact8>vesicular lesions noted on the tongue, gingiva, and lips, with some vesicles having ruptured and ulcerated</fact8>, the most likely causative organism is the one that typically causes oral and mucosal lesions. The patient's age, <fact1>5-year-old male</fact1>, and the duration of symptoms, <fact3>4 days</fact3>, also support a common viral infection. Among the options provided, HSV-1 is well-known for causing herpetic gingivostomatitis, which presents with similar symptoms such as <fact2>painful mouth/gums, and vesicular lesions</fact2>, <fact4>difficulty eating or drinking</fact4>, and <fact5>irritability</fact5>. Therefore, the most likely causative organism in this patient's presentation is {D}.

question:
A 40-year-old man presents to the physician with progressive weight loss for the last 3 months. He also says he frequently sweats profusely at night and has a recurring low-grade fever, for which he takes acetaminophen. The patient denies any symptoms like cough, breathlessness, or gastrointestinal symptoms. His temperature is 37.1ºC  (98.8ºF), pulse is 76/min, blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 13/min. On physical examination, he has generalized pallor. Bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Examination of his abdomen reveals non-tender hepatosplenomegaly in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory evaluation confirms the diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Which of the following viral infections is most likely to have played a role in the pathogenesis of this patient’s malignancy?
A) Cytomegalovirus
B) Epstein-Barr virus
C) Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1
D) Human herpesvirus-8
E) Human papillomavirus type 16
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>40-year-old man</fact1> presents to the physician with <fact2>progressive weight loss for the last 3 months</fact2>. He also says he frequently experiences <fact3>night sweats</fact3> and has a recurring <fact4>low-grade fever</fact4>, for which he takes acetaminophen. The patient denies any symptoms like cough, breathlessness, or gastrointestinal symptoms. His <fact5>temperature is 37.1ºC  (98.8ºF)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 76/min</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg</fact7>, and <fact8>respiratory rate is 13/min</fact8>. On physical examination, he has <fact9>generalized pallor</fact9>. <fact10>Bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy</fact10> is present. Examination of his abdomen reveals <fact11>non-tender hepatosplenomegaly in the right upper quadrant</fact11>. Laboratory evaluation confirms the diagnosis of <fact12>Hodgkin’s lymphoma</fact12>. Which of the following viral infections is most likely to have played a role in the pathogenesis of this patient’s malignancy?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's diagnosis of <fact12>Hodgkin’s lymphoma</fact12>, which is characterized by symptoms such as <fact2>progressive weight loss</fact2>, <fact3>night sweats</fact3>, and <fact4>low-grade fever</fact4>, along with physical findings of <fact9>generalized pallor</fact9>, <fact10>bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy</fact10>, and <fact11>non-tender hepatosplenomegaly</fact11>, we need to identify a viral infection known to be associated with this type of malignancy. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is well-documented to have a strong association with Hodgkin’s lymphoma, particularly in cases where the disease is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. Therefore, the viral infection most likely to have played a role in the pathogenesis of this patient’s malignancy is {B}.

question:
A 17-year-old man presents to his family physician for an evaluation about the size of his penis. He feels increasingly anxious during physical education (PE) class as he has noticed that the size of his penis is significantly smaller when compared to his peers. Based on the physical examination, he is Tanner stage 1. The weight and height are 60 kg (132 lb) and 175 cm (5 ft 9 in), respectively. The cardiopulmonary examination is normal; however, the patient has difficulty identifying coffee grounds by smell. Which of the following explains the pathophysiology underlying this patient’s disorder?
A) Expansion of a CTG trinucleotide repeat
B) Isolated gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) deficiency
C) Sex-specific epigenetic imprinting
D) Leptin receptor mutation
E) Non-disjunction of sex chromosomes
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>17-year-old man</fact1> presents to his family physician for an evaluation about the size of his <fact2>penis</fact2>. He feels increasingly anxious during physical education (PE) class as he has noticed that the size of his <fact2>penis</fact2> is significantly smaller when compared to his peers. Based on the physical examination, he is <fact3>Tanner stage 1</fact3>. The weight and height are <fact4>60 kg (132 lb)</fact4> and <fact5>175 cm (5 ft 9 in)</fact5>, respectively. The <fact6>cardiopulmonary examination</fact6> is normal; however, the patient has difficulty identifying <fact7>coffee grounds by smell</fact7>. Which of the following explains the pathophysiology underlying this patient’s disorder?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>17-year-old man</fact1> is at <fact3>Tanner stage 1</fact3>, indicating a lack of pubertal development, and his concern about the size of his <fact2>penis</fact2> compared to peers, it suggests a possible issue with his reproductive or endocrine system. Additionally, his difficulty identifying <fact7>coffee grounds by smell</fact7> points towards an issue with his sense of smell, which is often linked to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, specifically Kallmann syndrome. This condition is characterized by delayed or absent puberty and anosmia (loss of the sense of smell). The underlying pathophysiology of Kallmann syndrome involves <fact8>genetic mutations affecting the production or function of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH)</fact8>, but among the options provided, the closest explanation is related to the genetic basis of the disease. Therefore, the answer is {B} isolated gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) deficiency, as it closely aligns with the symptoms and underlying cause of Kallmann syndrome, though it's worth noting that Kallmann syndrome involves more than just isolated GnRH deficiency, as it also includes anosmia.

question:
A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of irregular menstrual bleeding. Menses have occurred at 45- to 90-day intervals since menarche at the age of 15 years. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. The patient reports that she was too embarrassed to discuss this issue with anyone until now. Over the past two years, she was unable to become pregnant despite having unprotected sexual intercourse with her husband on a regular basis. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 29.4 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows oily skin and severe facial acne. There is abnormal pigmented hair on the upper lip and around both nipples. The patient wishes to have children. In addition to recommending lifestyle modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate step in management?
A) In vitro fertilization with patient's egg
B) Progesterone therapy
C) Bromocriptine therapy
D) Clomiphene therapy
E) Leuprolide therapy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>22-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for the evaluation of <fact2>irregular menstrual bleeding</fact2>. Menses have occurred at <fact3>45- to 90-day intervals</fact3> since menarche at the age of 15 years. Her last menstrual period was <fact4>5 weeks ago</fact4>. The patient reports that she was too embarrassed to discuss this issue with anyone until now. Over the past two years, she was unable to become pregnant despite having <fact5>unprotected sexual intercourse with her husband on a regular basis</fact5>. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is <fact6>170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb)</fact6>; <fact7>BMI is 29.4 kg/m2</fact7>. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows <fact8>oily skin and severe facial acne</fact8>. There is abnormal pigmented hair on the upper lip and around both nipples. The patient wishes to have children. In addition to recommending lifestyle modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>irregular menstrual bleeding</fact2> with <fact3>45- to 90-day intervals</fact3> between menses, <fact8>oily skin and severe facial acne</fact8>, and the presence of abnormal pigmented hair, these signs are indicative of hyperandrogenism and anovulation, which are hallmarks of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). Given her <fact5>difficulty becoming pregnant despite regular unprotected intercourse</fact5> and her desire to have children, the most appropriate management step would be to induce ovulation. Among the options provided, Clomiphene therapy is a common first-line treatment for inducing ovulation in women with PCOS. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 25-year-old zookeeper presents to the office complaining of a dry cough, fever, and chills for the past month. He states that the symptoms come in episodes at the end of the workday and last a few hours. He also mentions that he is fatigued all the time. His job includes taking care of various types of birds. He is otherwise fine and denies recent travel or trauma. Medical history is unremarkable and he does not take any medications. He does not smoke cigarettes or drinks alcohol. Allergies include peanuts, dust, and pollen. Childhood asthma runs in the family. Chest X-ray reveals diffuse haziness in both lower lung fields. A PPD skin test is negative. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
A) Thoracocentesis
B) Inhaled beclomethasone
C) Avoid exposure to birds
D) Isoniazid for 6 months
E) Reassurance
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old zookeeper</fact1> presents to the office complaining of a <fact2>dry cough, fever, and chills</fact2> for the past month. He states that the symptoms come in episodes at the end of the workday and last a few hours. He also mentions that he is <fact3>fatigued all the time</fact3>. His job includes taking care of <fact4>various types of birds</fact4>. He is otherwise fine and denies recent travel or trauma. Medical history is unremarkable and he does not take any medications. He does not smoke cigarettes or drinks alcohol. Allergies include peanuts, dust, and pollen. Childhood asthma runs in the family. <fact5>Chest X-ray reveals diffuse haziness in both lower lung fields</fact5>. A <fact6>PPD skin test is negative</fact6>. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's occupation as a <fact1>25-year-old zookeeper</fact1> and his exposure to <fact4>various types of birds</fact4>, along with the symptoms of <fact2>dry cough, fever, and chills</fact2> and <fact3>fatigue</fact3>, the most likely diagnosis is bird fancier's lung or avian hypersensitivity pneumonitis. This condition is caused by an allergic reaction to proteins found in bird droppings and feathers. The <fact5>diffuse haziness in both lower lung fields</fact5> on the chest X-ray supports this diagnosis. Given the negative <fact6>PPD skin test</fact6>, tuberculosis is less likely. The most appropriate treatment for this patient is to <fact7>avoid exposure to birds</fact7>, which is the primary allergen causing his symptoms. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation comes to the physician for shortness of breath with mild exertion, progressive weakness, and a dry cough that has persisted for 6 months. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. His medications include warfarin, enalapril, and amiodarone. His pulse is 85/min and irregularly irregular. Physical examination shows enlarged fingertips and markedly curved nails. A CT scan of the chest shows clustered air spaces and reticular opacities in the basal parts of the lung. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's dyspnea?
A) Chronic airway inflammation
B) Bronchial hyperresponsiveness and obstruction
C) Fluid leak into the interstitium and alveoli
D) Pleural scarring
E) Excess collagen deposition in the extracellular matrix of the lung
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>70-year-old man</fact1> with a history of <fact2>hypertension and atrial fibrillation</fact2> comes to the physician for <fact3>shortness of breath with mild exertion, progressive weakness, and a dry cough</fact3> that has persisted for <fact4>6 months</fact4>. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for <fact5>45 years</fact5>. His medications include <fact6>warfarin, enalapril, and amiodarone</fact6>. His <fact7>pulse is 85/min and irregularly irregular</fact7>. Physical examination shows <fact8>enlarged fingertips and markedly curved nails</fact8>. A <fact9>CT scan of the chest</fact9> shows <fact10>clustered air spaces and reticular opacities in the basal parts of the lung</fact10>. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's <fact11>dyspnea</fact11>?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact3>shortness of breath with mild exertion, progressive weakness, and a dry cough</fact3> that have persisted for <fact4>6 months</fact4>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact8>enlarged fingertips and markedly curved nails</fact8>, which are indicative of clubbing, a sign often associated with chronic lung diseases. The <fact9>CT scan of the chest</fact9> showing <fact10>clustered air spaces and reticular opacities in the basal parts of the lung</fact10> further supports the presence of an interstitial lung disease. Given the patient's long history of smoking <fact5>45 years</fact5>, the most likely underlying mechanism of his <fact11>dyspnea</fact11> is related to the effects of chronic smoking on the lungs. Among the options provided, excess collagen deposition in the extracellular matrix of the lung is a hallmark of fibrotic lung diseases, which can be caused by smoking. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 28-year-old G1P0 woman at 12 weeks estimated gestational age presents with malaise, joint pain, fever, and chills for the past 3 days. Physical examination reveals a mild lace-like rash and arthritis. The patient mentions her friend who is a medical student told her that her symptoms are suggestive of a parvovirus B19 infection which may adversely affect her baby. Which of the following statements regarding the effect of parvovirus B19 infection in this pregnant patient is correct?
A) It can lead to hydrops fetalis secondary to fetal anemia.
B) It can cause aplastic crisis in the neonate.
C) Physical malformations are frequently associated with congenital infection.
D) Fetal loss occurs in more than 40% of primary infections.
E) The neonate may be born with a typical slapped-cheek rash.
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>28-year-old G1P0 woman</fact1> at <fact2>12 weeks estimated gestational age</fact2> presents with <fact3>malaise, joint pain, fever, and chills</fact3> for the past <fact4>3 days</fact4>. Physical examination reveals a <fact5>mild lace-like rash</fact5> and <fact6>arthritis</fact6>. The patient mentions her friend who is a medical student told her that her symptoms are suggestive of a <fact7>parvovirus B19 infection</fact7> which may adversely affect her baby. Which of the following statements regarding the effect of <fact7>parvovirus B19 infection</fact7> in this pregnant patient is correct?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>28-year-old G1P0 woman</fact1> is at <fact2>12 weeks estimated gestational age</fact2> and presents with symptoms suggestive of a <fact7>parvovirus B19 infection</fact7>, such as <fact3>malaise, joint pain, fever, and chills</fact3>, <fact5>mild lace-like rash</fact5>, and <fact6>arthritis</fact6>, it is essential to evaluate the potential effects of this infection on her baby. Among the provided options, the statement that <fact7>parvovirus B19 infection</fact7> can lead to hydrops fetalis secondary to fetal anemia is correct. This condition occurs because the virus can cause severe anemia in the fetus, leading to heart failure and subsequent hydrops fetalis. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife for incomprehensible speech. Upon first inspection you note the man is drooling and his eyes are tearing excessively. The patient's wife explains that the man was tilling the fields on the family beet farm when she found him collapsed on a pile of freshly picked beets. The patient seemed confused so the wife brought him in promptly, and states it has only been ten minutes since the patient was found down in the fields. Physical exam is deferred due to a confused and combative patient who is speaking clearly yet his sentences do not make any sense. The patients clothes are removed in the ED. Vital signs are currently being obtained. Which of the following is the best initial step in management?
A) Sublingual atropine drops
B) Neostigmine
C) Physostigmine
D) 2-pralidoxime
E) Intubation
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>70-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by his wife for <fact2>incomprehensible speech</fact2>. Upon first inspection you note the man is <fact3>drooling and his eyes are tearing excessively</fact3>. The patient's wife explains that the man was <fact4>tilling the fields on the family beet farm</fact4> when she found him collapsed on a pile of <fact5>freshly picked beets</fact5>. The patient seemed <fact6>confused</fact6> so the wife brought him in promptly, and states it has only been <fact7>ten minutes</fact7> since the patient was found down in the fields. Physical exam is deferred due to a <fact8>confused and combative patient</fact8> who is speaking clearly yet his sentences do not make any sense. The patient's clothes are removed in the ED. Vital signs are currently being obtained. Which of the following is the best initial step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>incomprehensible speech</fact2>, <fact3>drooling and excessive tearing</fact3>, and being <fact8>confused and combative</fact8>, along with the context of being found collapsed on a pile of <fact5>freshly picked beets</fact5> in the fields, there is a strong indication of organophosphate poisoning, commonly associated with agricultural pesticides. Given this scenario, the best initial step in management would be to administer atropine, which is an antidote for organophosphate poisoning. However, since the patient is <fact8>confused and combative</fact8>, ensuring a secure airway is crucial before administering any medication. Therefore, the best initial step is intubation to secure the airway, followed by administration of atropine. The answer is {E}.

question:
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, at 22 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department for abdominal pain and heavy vaginal bleeding for 2 hours. She has had no prenatal care. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. The abdomen is nontender, and regular contractions are felt every 2 minutes. The uterus is consistent in size with a 20-week gestation. There is blood on the vulva, introitus, and medial aspect of the thighs. Ultrasound shows complete detachment of the placenta from the uterus. Fetal heart tones are absent. An emergent cesarean delivery is performed. Following the procedure, the patient becomes tearful and distraught. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
A) “I'm sorry for your loss. This must be a difficult situation for you.”
B) “Losing a baby is difficult, but I'm sure next time it'll work out.”
C) “I'm sorry for your loss. Let's talk about how to move forward from here.”
D) “Losing a baby is difficult; but I see this every day, and I know you'll get through it.”
E) “I'm sorry for your loss. I can write you a prescription to help with your anxiety and grief.”
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, at 22 weeks' gestation</fact1> comes to the emergency department for <fact2>abdominal pain and heavy vaginal bleeding</fact2> for 2 hours. She has had <fact3>no prenatal care</fact3>. Her <fact4>temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F)</fact4>, <fact5>pulse is 102/min</fact5>, <fact6>respirations are 16/min</fact6>, and <fact7>blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg</fact7>. The abdomen is <fact8>nontender</fact8>, and <fact9>regular contractions are felt every 2 minutes</fact9>. The uterus is consistent in size with a <fact10>20-week gestation</fact10>. There is <fact11>blood on the vulva, introitus, and medial aspect of the thighs</fact11>. Ultrasound shows <fact12>complete detachment of the placenta from the uterus</fact12>. <fact13>Fetal heart tones are absent</fact13>. An <fact14>emergent cesarean delivery</fact14> is performed. Following the procedure, the patient becomes <fact15>tearful and distraught</fact15>. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's situation, having experienced a pregnancy loss at <fact10>20-week gestation</fact10> with <fact13>fetal heart tones absent</fact13> and undergoing an <fact14>emergent cesarean delivery</fact14>, she is understandably <fact15>tearful and distraught</fact15>. The most appropriate initial response by the physician should acknowledge her loss and validate her feelings. Option A, “I'm sorry for your loss. This must be a difficult situation for you,” is the most empathetic response as it directly addresses her current emotional state without minimizing her feelings or rushing to discuss future actions. This response allows the patient to feel heard and understood, which is crucial in the initial stages of grief.

question:
A 42-year-old chronic alcoholic man was admitted to the hospital for inappropriate behavior and disturbed memory. He presents with severe retrograde memory loss, confusion, and confabulation. Neurologic examination showed horizontal nystagmus. He also has bilateral pretibial pitting edema and perioral erythema. CT studies of the brain were normal. The duty physician suspects the patient may be vitamin deficient. Which of the following reactions does the deficient vitamin mediate?
A) Alpha-Ketoglutarate + NAD+ + CoA <=> Succinyl-CoA + CO2 + NADH
B) Acetyl-CoA + Oxaloacetate + H2O <=> Citrate + CoA + H+
C) Succinate + FAD (enzyme bound) <=> Fumarate + FADH2
D) Isocitrate + NAD+ <=> Alpha-Ketoglutarate + CO2 + NADH
E) Succinyl-CoA + Pi + GDP <=> Succinate + GTP + CoA
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>42-year-old chronic alcoholic man</fact1> was admitted to the hospital for <fact2>inappropriate behavior and disturbed memory</fact2>. He presents with <fact3>severe retrograde memory loss, confusion, and confabulation</fact3>. <fact4>Neurologic examination</fact4> showed <fact5>horizontal nystagmus</fact5>. He also has <fact6>bilateral pretibial pitting edema</fact6> and <fact7>perioral erythema</fact7>. <fact8>CT studies of the brain</fact8> were normal. The duty physician suspects the patient may be <fact9>vitamin deficient</fact9>. Which of the following reactions does the deficient vitamin mediate?

A) Alpha-Ketoglutarate + NAD+ + CoA <=> Succinyl-CoA + CO2 + NADH
B) Acetyl-CoA + Oxaloacetate + H2O <=> Citrate + CoA + H+
C) Succinate + FAD (enzyme bound) <=> Fumarate + FADH2
D) Isocitrate + NAD+ <=> Alpha-Ketoglutarate + CO2 + NADH
E) Succinyl-CoA + Pi + GDP <=> Succinate + GTP + CoA

Answer: 
Considering the symptoms presented by the <fact1>42-year-old chronic alcoholic man</fact1>, including <fact3>severe retrograde memory loss, confusion, and confabulation</fact3>, along with <fact5>horizontal nystagmus</fact5>, <fact6>bilateral pretibial pitting edema</fact6>, and <fact7>perioral erythema</fact7>, it is suggestive of a condition associated with thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, known as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. Thiamine plays a crucial role in energy metabolism and is a coenzyme for several important biochemical reactions. Among the options provided, the reaction that thiamine mediates as part of the alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex is: Alpha-Ketoglutarate + NAD+ + CoA <=> Succinyl-CoA + CO2 + NADH. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 22-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician in April for seasonal allergies. She has suffered from seasonal allergies for the past 2 years and takes diphenhydramine as needed when her symptoms worsen. She has not yet seen a physician for her allergies. She reports that diphenhydramine has been helpful in controlling her symptoms, but she does not like feeling drowsy from the medication. Her past medical history is also notable for well-controlled asthma. She uses an albuterol inhaler on an as-needed basis. She smokes marijuana daily. Her temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 16/min. She has a prominent nasal crease. Her nasal turbinates are boggy and bluish-gray. She has copious thin and watery nasal mucus. The physician suggests replacing diphenhydramine with fexofenadine to improve her drowsiness. What characteristic of fexodenadine allows it to be less sedating than diphenhydramine?
A) Alpha-adrenergic antagonism
B) Beta-adrenergic antagonism
C) Muscarinic antagonism
D) Relative lipophobicity
E) Serotonergic antagonism
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>22-year-old woman</fact1> presents to her primary care physician in April for <fact2>seasonal allergies</fact2>. She has suffered from <fact2>seasonal allergies</fact2> for the past 2 years and takes <fact3>diphenhydramine</fact3> as needed when her symptoms worsen. She has not yet seen a physician for her <fact2>allergies</fact2>. She reports that <fact3>diphenhydramine</fact3> has been helpful in controlling her symptoms, but she does not like feeling <fact4>drowsy from the medication</fact4>. Her past medical history is also notable for <fact5>well-controlled asthma</fact5>. She uses an <fact6>albuterol inhaler</fact6> on an as-needed basis. She <fact7>smokes marijuana daily</fact7>. Her <fact8>temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 76/min</fact10>, and <fact11>respirations are 16/min</fact11>. She has a <fact12>prominent nasal crease</fact12>. Her <fact13>nasal turbinates are boggy and bluish-gray</fact13>. She has <fact14>copious thin and watery nasal mucus</fact14>. The physician suggests replacing <fact3>diphenhydramine</fact3> with <fact15>fexofenadine</fact15> to improve her <fact4>drowsiness</fact4>. What characteristic of <fact15>fexofenadine</fact15> allows it to be less sedating than <fact3>diphenhydramine</fact3>?

Answer: 
The key to answering this question lies in understanding the properties of <fact15>fexofenadine</fact15> that distinguish it from <fact3>diphenhydramine</fact3>, particularly in terms of sedation. <fact3>Diphenhydramine</fact3> is known to cause <fact4>drowsiness</fact4> due to its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier, a characteristic often associated with lipophilicity. Therefore, the characteristic of <fact15>fexofenadine</fact15> that allows it to be less sedating than <fact3>diphenhydramine</fact3> is its relative lipophobicity, which reduces its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier and cause sedation. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 45-year-old man presents to the doctor’s office with shortness of breath, cough, and fatigue for 3 days. This has been progressively worsening. He has a medical history significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and osteoarthritis. He takes albuterol, ipratropium and aspirin. He smoked 2 and a half packs per day, and had done so for the past 26 years. After ceasing tobacco use for 1 year, he has recently begun smoking again. The blood pressure is 138/88 mm Hg, the respiratory rate is 12/min, the heart rate is 76/min, and the pulse oximetry is 87% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears disoriented and is only somewhat comprehensible. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light with extraocular movements intact. Cranial nerves VII-XII also intact. The auscultation of the heart is absent of murmur, rubs, or gallops. The auscultation of the lungs demonstrate audible rales in the bases bilaterally. Which of the stages of change is the patient currently experiencing based on the clinical vignette?
A) Precontemplation
B) Contemplation
C) Preparation
D) Maintenance
E) Relapse
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old man</fact1> presents to the doctor’s office with <fact2>shortness of breath, cough, and fatigue for 3 days</fact2>. This has been progressively worsening. He has a medical history significant for <fact3>chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and osteoarthritis</fact3>. He takes <fact4>albuterol, ipratropium and aspirin</fact4>. He <fact5>smoked 2 and a half packs per day, and had done so for the past 26 years</fact5>. After <fact6>ceasing tobacco use for 1 year</fact6>, he has recently <fact7>begun smoking again</fact7>. The <fact8>blood pressure is 138/88 mm Hg, the respiratory rate is 12/min, the heart rate is 76/min, and the pulse oximetry is 87% on room air</fact8>. On physical examination, the patient appears <fact9>disoriented and is only somewhat comprehensible</fact9>. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light with extraocular movements intact. Cranial nerves VII-XII also intact. The auscultation of the heart is absent of murmur, rubs, or gallops. The auscultation of the lungs demonstrate audible rales in the bases bilaterally. Which of the stages of change is the patient currently experiencing based on the clinical vignette?

Answer: 
The patient had <fact6>ceased tobacco use for 1 year</fact6> but has recently <fact7>begun smoking again</fact7>. This indicates that the patient had previously made a change (quitting smoking) but has reverted to the old behavior (smoking again). According to the stages of change model, this scenario best fits the "relapse" stage, where an individual returns to a previous behavior after having made a change. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 15-year-old female presents to her pediatrician’s office for severe menstrual cramping. The patient underwent menarche at age 11, and her periods were irregular every 2-3 months for two years. After that, her cycles became roughly regular every 28-35 days, but she has had extremely painful cramps and often has to miss school. The cramps are intermittent and feel like a dull ache in the center of her abdomen, and there is usually accompanying back pain. The patient has been using heating pads with limited relief. She reports some periods being “really heavy” and requires a superabsorbent pad every 6 hours for 2 days each cycle, but this does not limit her activities. She denies any bowel or bladder changes. The patient had normal development throughout childhood, is on the soccer team at school, and is not sexually active. Her father has hypertension and her mother has endometriosis and heavy periods. On exam, the patient is 5 feet 5 inches and weighs 158 pounds (BMI 26.3 kg/m^2). She is well appearing and has no abdominal tenderness. She has Tanner IV breasts and Tanner IV pubic hair, and external genitalia are normal. Which of the following is the best next step for this patient’s menstrual cramps?
A) Von Willebrand factor antigen assay
B) Pelvic ultrasound
C) MRI of the pelvis
D) NSAIDs
E) Increased exercise
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>15-year-old female</fact1> presents to her pediatrician’s office for <fact2>severe menstrual cramping</fact2>. The patient underwent <fact3>menarche at age 11</fact3>, and her periods were <fact4>irregular every 2-3 months for two years</fact4>. After that, her cycles became roughly <fact5>regular every 28-35 days</fact5>, but she has had <fact6>extremely painful cramps</fact6> and often has to miss school. The cramps are <fact7>intermittent and feel like a dull ache in the center of her abdomen</fact7>, and there is usually accompanying <fact8>back pain</fact8>. The patient has been using <fact9>heating pads with limited relief</fact9>. She reports some periods being “<fact10>really heavy”</fact10> and requires a <fact11>superabsorbent pad every 6 hours for 2 days each cycle</fact11>, but this does not limit her activities. She denies any <fact12>bowel or bladder changes</fact12>. The patient had <fact13>normal development throughout childhood</fact13>, is on the <fact14>soccer team at school</fact14>, and is not <fact15>sexually active</fact15>. Her <fact16>father has hypertension</fact16> and her <fact17>mother has endometriosis and heavy periods</fact17>. On exam, the patient is <fact18>5 feet 5 inches and weighs 158 pounds (BMI 26.3 kg/m^2)</fact18>. She is <fact19>well appearing and has no abdominal tenderness</fact19>. She has <fact20>Tanner IV breasts and Tanner IV pubic hair</fact20>, and <fact21>external genitalia are normal</fact21>. Which of the following is the best next step for this patient’s menstrual cramps?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>severe menstrual cramping</fact2> and <fact6>extremely painful cramps</fact6> that are <fact7>intermittent and feel like a dull ache in the center of her abdomen</fact7> with accompanying <fact8>back pain</fact8>, the best initial approach would be to manage her pain. Since she has already tried <fact9>heating pads with limited relief</fact9>, the next step would be to consider medication for pain relief. Among the options provided, NSAIDs (Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs) are commonly used for menstrual cramp pain management and would be an appropriate next step before considering more invasive diagnostic procedures. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a persistent cough, fever, and vomiting. The past year the child has been admitted to the hospital 3 times with pneumonia. For the past 1 week, the child has been experiencing thick purulent cough and says that her chest feels ‘heavy’. Her stools have been loose and foul-smelling over the past week. Her parents are also concerned that she has not gained much weight due to her frequent hospital visits. She was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery and is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. On physical exam, the temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). She appears lethargic and uncomfortable. Crackles are heard in the lower lung bases, with dullness to percussion. A small nasal polyp is also present on inspection. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the girl’s symptoms?
A) Dysfunction in a transmembrane regulator
B) Inefficient breakdown of leucine, isoleucine, and valine
C) Dysfunction in the motility of respiratory cilia
D) Acute hypersensitivity changes and bronchospasm
E) Deficiency in lymphocytic activity
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>4-year-old girl</fact1> is brought to the emergency department with a <fact2>persistent cough, fever, and vomiting</fact2>. The past year the child has been admitted to the hospital <fact3>3 times with pneumonia</fact3>. For the past <fact4>1 week</fact4>, the child has been experiencing <fact5>thick purulent cough</fact5> and says that her chest feels ‘heavy’. Her stools have been <fact6>loose and foul-smelling</fact6> over the past week. Her parents are also concerned that she has not gained much weight due to her <fact7>frequent hospital visits</fact7>. She was born at <fact8>39 weeks gestation</fact8> via spontaneous vaginal delivery and is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. On physical exam, the <fact9>temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F)</fact9>. She appears <fact10>lethargic and uncomfortable</fact10>. <fact11>Crackles are heard in the lower lung bases, with dullness to percussion</fact11>. A <fact12>small nasal polyp</fact12> is also present on inspection. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the girl’s symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>4-year-old girl's</fact1> history of <fact3>3 times with pneumonia</fact3> in the past year, along with her current symptoms of <fact2>persistent cough, fever, and vomiting</fact2>, and <fact5>thick purulent cough</fact5>, it suggests a chronic respiratory condition. The presence of a <fact12>small nasal polyp</fact12> also points towards a condition that affects the respiratory tract. Additionally, her <fact6>loose and foul-smelling stools</fact6> could indicate malabsorption issues. Given these factors, the most likely cause for the girl's symptoms is a dysfunction in a transmembrane regulator, which is characteristic of Cystic Fibrosis. This condition affects the respiratory, digestive, and reproductive systems and is consistent with her symptoms and medical history. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance from a soccer game. During the game, he was about to kick the ball when another player collided with his leg from the front. He was unable to stand up after this collision and reported severe knee pain. On presentation, he was found to have a mild knee effusion. Physical exam showed that his knee could be pushed posteriorly at 90 degrees of flexion but it could not be pulled anteriorly in the same position. The anatomic structure that was most likely injured in this patient has which of the following characteristics?
A) Runs anteriorly from the lateral femoral condyle
B) Runs anteriorly from the medial femoral condyle
C) Runs medially from the lateral femoral condyle
D) Runs posteriorly from the lateral femoral condyle
E) Runs posteriorly from the medial femoral condyle
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>16-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by ambulance from a soccer game. During the game, he was about to kick the ball when another player collided with his leg from the <fact2>front</fact2>. He was unable to stand up after this collision and reported severe <fact3>knee pain</fact3>. On presentation, he was found to have a mild <fact4>knee effusion</fact4>. Physical exam showed that his knee could be pushed <fact5>posteriorly at 90 degrees of flexion</fact5> but it could not be pulled <fact6>anteriorly in the same position</fact6>. The anatomic structure that was most likely injured in this patient has which of the following characteristics?

Answer: 
Considering the mechanism of injury where the player collided with the patient's leg from the <fact2>front</fact2>, along with the inability to pull the knee <fact6>anteriorly in the same position</fact6> and the ability to push it <fact5>posteriorly at 90 degrees of flexion</fact5>, suggests an injury to the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL). The PCL originates from the <fact7>posterior aspect of the lateral surface of the femur in the intercondylar notch</fact7>, however, that detail is not provided in the question, but among the options given, option D describes a structure that runs posteriorly from the lateral femoral condyle, which is most consistent with the PCL. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 39-year-old man presents to his primary care physician because he has been having severe headaches and fever for the last 2 days. He also says his right eyelid has been painlessly swelling and is starting to block his vision from that eye. He recently returned from a tour of the world where he visited Thailand, Ethiopia, and Brazil. Otherwise his past medical history is unremarkable. On presentation, his temperature is 102°F (38.8°C), blood pressure is 126/81 mmHg, pulse is 125/min, and respirations are 13/min. Physical exam reveals a nontender swelling of the right eyelid, lymphadenopathy, and an indurated red patch with surrounding erythema and local swelling on his left leg. Which of the following drugs should be used to treat this patient's condition?
A) Benznidazole
B) Diethylcarbamazine
C) Ivermectin
D) Mebendazol
E) Sodium stibogluconate
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>39-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care physician because he has been having <fact2>severe headaches and fever</fact2> for the last <fact3>2 days</fact3>. He also says his <fact4>right eyelid has been painlessly swelling</fact4> and is starting to block his vision from that eye. He recently returned from a tour of the world where he visited <fact5>Thailand, Ethiopia, and Brazil</fact5>. Otherwise his past medical history is unremarkable. On presentation, his <fact6>temperature is 102°F (38.8°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 126/81 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 125/min</fact8>, and <fact9>respirations are 13/min</fact9>. Physical exam reveals a <fact10>nontender swelling of the right eyelid</fact10>, <fact11>lymphadenopathy</fact11>, and an <fact12>indurated red patch with surrounding erythema and local swelling on his left leg</fact12>. Which of the following drugs should be used to treat this patient's condition?

A) Benznidazole
B) Diethylcarbamazine
C) Ivermectin
D) Mebendazol
E) Sodium stibogluconate

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>severe headaches and fever</fact2>, <fact4>painless swelling of the right eyelid</fact4>, and an <fact12>indurated red patch on his left leg</fact12>, along with <fact11>lymphadenopathy</fact11>, the clinical presentation is suggestive of leishmaniasis, which is a disease caused by Leishmania parasites that the patient could have been exposed to during his travel to <fact5>Thailand, Ethiopia, or Brazil</fact5>. Sodium stibogluconate is a medication used to treat leishmaniasis. Therefore, the correct answer is {E}.

question:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever, cough, purulent nasal discharge. She has experienced 7 similar episodes, each lasting 2–5 days in the previous 2 years. She has also had intermittent abdominal cramps and recurrent episodes of foul-smelling greasy diarrhea in the past year. She is at the 55th percentile for height and 35th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an erythematous oropharynx without exudate and tenderness over the frontoethmoidal sinuses. The abdomen is distended, nontender, and tympanitic to percussion. Bowel sounds are increased. Stool microscopy shows pear-shaped multi-flagellated organisms. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following?
A) Progressive peripheral neuropathy
B) Anaphylactic transfusion reactions
C) Cutaneous granulomas
D) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
E) Disseminated tuberculosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>3-year-old girl</fact1> is brought to the physician because of a <fact2>3-day history of fever, cough, purulent nasal discharge</fact2>. She has experienced <fact3>7 similar episodes, each lasting 2–5 days in the previous 2 years</fact3>. She has also had <fact4>intermittent abdominal cramps</fact4> and <fact5>recurrent episodes of foul-smelling greasy diarrhea</fact5> in the past year. She is at the <fact6>55th percentile for height and 35th percentile for weight</fact6>. Her <fact7>temperature is 38.9°C (102°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 100/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 24/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg</fact10>. Physical examination shows an <fact11>erythematous oropharynx without exudate</fact11> and <fact12>tenderness over the frontoethmoidal sinuses</fact12>. The <fact13>abdomen is distended, nontender, and tympanitic to percussion</fact13>. <fact14>Bowel sounds are increased</fact14>. <fact15>Stool microscopy shows pear-shaped multi-flagellated organisms</fact15>. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>recurrent respiratory infections</fact2> and <fact5>gastrointestinal issues such as foul-smelling greasy diarrhea</fact5>, along with the finding of <fact15>pear-shaped multi-flagellated organisms in the stool</fact15>, the patient likely has a primary immunodeficiency, specifically an antibody deficiency, given the <fact3>frequency and duration of infections</fact3>. The presence of <fact15>Giardia lamblia</fact15> in the stool, as indicated by the <fact15>pear-shaped multi-flagellated organisms</fact15>, further supports this, as patients with antibody deficiencies are more susceptible to giardiasis. Among the options provided, the increased risk for <fact16>disseminated infections or malignancies</fact16> is a concern in patients with primary immunodeficiencies. However, given the choices, the most directly related risk is not explicitly listed, but we can infer that a patient with recurrent infections and an inability to clear pathogens like Giardia would be at increased risk for complications related to those infections. The closest answer related to an increased risk due to an immunocompromised state would be {E}, Disseminated tuberculosis, as an example of a disseminated infection, although the direct link to Giardia infection and the patient's symptoms is not explicitly tuberculosis.

question:
Six days after undergoing surgical repair of a hip fracture, a previously healthy 79-year-old woman is agitated and confused. She is unarousable during the day, but then is awake and impulsive during the night, requiring frequent reorientation. Her husband says that she usually drinks one to two glasses of wine weekly. Her only current medication is oxycodone for pain. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is distressed and oriented to person but not to place or time. Neurologic examination shows inattentiveness but no focal deficits. Urine dipstick is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her current condition?
A) Dementia
B) Alcohol withdrawal
C) Opioid intoxication
D) Delirium
E) Urinary tract infection
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
Six days after undergoing surgical repair of a <fact1>hip fracture</fact1>, a previously healthy <fact2>79-year-old woman</fact2> is <fact3>agitated and confused</fact3>. She is <fact4>unarousable during the day, but then is awake and impulsive during the night</fact4>, requiring frequent reorientation. Her husband says that she usually drinks <fact5>one to two glasses of wine weekly</fact5>. Her only current medication is <fact6>oxycodone for pain</fact6>. Her <fact7>vital signs are within normal limits</fact7>. She is <fact8>distressed and oriented to person but not to place or time</fact8>. Neurologic examination shows <fact9>inattentiveness but no focal deficits</fact9>. <fact10>Urine dipstick is normal</fact10>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her current condition?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the <fact2>79-year-old woman</fact2> is experiencing <fact3>agitation and confusion</fact3> six days after surgery for a <fact1>hip fracture</fact1>. Her pattern of being <fact4>unarousable during the day but awake and impulsive at night</fact4> is indicative of a disrupted sleep-wake cycle. Given her age and recent surgery, she is at high risk for delirium, which is characterized by an acute onset of fluctuating cognitive impairment, including <fact8>distress and disorientation</fact8> as well as <fact9>inattentiveness without focal neurologic deficits</fact9>. The fact that her <fact7>vital signs are within normal limits</fact7> and <fact10>urine dipstick is normal</fact10> helps rule out other acute medical causes. Her minimal alcohol use of <fact5>one to two glasses of wine weekly</fact5> makes alcohol withdrawal unlikely, and while <fact6>oxycodone for pain</fact6> could contribute to confusion, the overall clinical picture is more suggestive of delirium. Therefore, the most likely cause of her current condition is {D}.

question:
A group of researchers decided to explore whether the estimates of incidence and prevalence rates of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) were influenced by the number of years it took to examine administrative data. These estimates were not only based on hospital discharges, but also on physician billing codes. For study purposes, the researchers labeled incident cases at the initial occurrence of SLE diagnosis in the hospital database, while prevalent cases were those that were coded as harboring SLE at any time, with patients maintaining their diagnosis until death. Which statement is true regarding the relationship between incidence and prevalence rates during the time period that might be chosen for this specific study?
A) Examining successively longer time periods will result in substantially lower prevalence estimates.
B) Incidence rates will be higher during shorter time periods than longer periods.
C) The prevalence of SLE during consecutively shorter time windows will be overestimated.
D) The inclusion of attack rates would increase incidence estimates in longer time periods.
E) The inclusion of attack rates would decrease incidence estimates in shorter time periods.
answer:
Reformatted Question: A group of researchers decided to explore whether the estimates of <fact1>incidence and prevalence rates</fact1> of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) were influenced by the <fact2>number of years it took to examine administrative data</fact2>. These estimates were not only based on <fact3>hospital discharges</fact3>, but also on <fact4>physician billing codes</fact4>. For study purposes, the researchers labeled <fact5>incident cases</fact5> at the initial occurrence of SLE diagnosis in the hospital database, while <fact6>prevalent cases</fact6> were those that were coded as harboring SLE at any time, with patients maintaining their diagnosis until death. Which statement is true regarding the relationship between <fact1>incidence and prevalence rates</fact1> during the time period that might be chosen for this specific study?

Answer: Considering the definitions provided in the study, <fact5>incident cases</fact5> are those that are newly diagnosed, while <fact6>prevalent cases</fact6> include both new and existing cases. As the <fact2>number of years it took to examine administrative data</fact2> increases, more existing cases are likely to be captured, leading to higher <fact6>prevalence rates</fact6>. Conversely, the rate of new cases (<fact5>incidence rate</fact5>) is less likely to be affected by the duration of the study period, as it only counts new occurrences. Therefore, examining successively longer time periods will likely result in higher prevalence estimates due to the accumulation of existing cases, but the incidence rate should remain relatively stable. Among the options provided, choice C suggests that the prevalence of SLE during consecutively shorter time windows will be overestimated, which is incorrect based on the reasoning above. However, none of the options directly state the correct relationship as described. The closest correct interpretation based on the given options and the context provided would be that none of the statements accurately describe the relationship in the context given, but based on typical epidemiological principles, we can infer a correct relationship: The prevalence of SLE during consecutively longer time windows will be higher due to the accumulation of cases over time, which contradicts the statements provided.

question:
A 25-year-old female with Hodgkin's lymphoma presents with a several day history of edema. Lab studies show:

Serum Na+: 140 mmol/L
Serum K+: 3.5 mmol/L
Serum albumin: 1.9 g/dL
Total serum bilirubin: 1.0 mg/dL
Serum creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL

Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria and fatty casts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
B) Membranous nephropathy
C) Minimal change disease
D) Amyloidosis
E) Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old female with Hodgkin's lymphoma</fact1> presents with a several day history of <fact2>edema</fact2>. Lab studies show:

<fact3>Serum Na+: 140 mmol/L</fact3>
<fact4>Serum K+: 3.5 mmol/L</fact4>
<fact5>Serum albumin: 1.9 g/dL</fact5>
<fact6>Total serum bilirubin: 1.0 mg/dL</fact6>
<fact7>Serum creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL</fact7>

Urinalysis shows <fact8>4+ proteinuria</fact8> and <fact9>fatty casts</fact9>. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact1>history of Hodgkin's lymphoma</fact1> and the presentation of <fact2>edema</fact2>, along with the laboratory findings of <fact5>low serum albumin</fact5> and <fact8>4+ proteinuria</fact8> with <fact9>fatty casts</fact9> in the urinalysis, the most likely diagnosis is Minimal Change Disease (MCD). MCD is often associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma and is characterized by significant proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia, which are evident in this patient's lab results. The presence of fatty casts in the urine further supports this diagnosis, as they are indicative of significant protein loss through the kidneys. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
An 81-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her son after witnessing the patient fall and hit her head. The son reports that the patient was in her usual state of health until she complained of chest palpitations. This startled her while she was climbing down the stairs and lead to a fall. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and atrial fibrillation. Medications are lisinopril, metoprolol, and warfarin. Temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 152/96 mmHg, pulse is 60/min, respirations are 12/min, and pulse oximetry is 98% on room air. On physical examination, she is disoriented and at times difficult to arouse, the left pupil is 6 mm and non-reactive to light, and the right pupil is 2 mm and reactive to light. A right-sided visual field defect is appreciated on visual field testing. There is 1/5 strength on the right upper and lower extremity; as well as 5/5 strength in the left upper and lower extremity. A computerized tomography (CT) scan of the head is shown. Which of the following most likely explains this patient’s symptoms?
A) Herniation of the uncus
B) Herniation of the cingulate gyrus
C) Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery
D) Occlusion of the basilar artery
E) Occlusion of the anterior spinal artery
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An <fact1>81-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency room by her son after witnessing the patient <fact2>fall and hit her head</fact2>. The son reports that the patient was in her usual state of health until she complained of <fact3>chest palpitations</fact3>. This startled her while she was climbing down the stairs and led to a fall. Past medical history is significant for <fact4>hypertension and atrial fibrillation</fact4>. Medications are <fact5>lisinopril, metoprolol, and warfarin</fact5>. <fact6>Temperature is 99°F (37.2°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 152/96 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 60/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 12/min</fact9>, and <fact10>pulse oximetry is 98% on room air</fact10>. On physical examination, she is <fact11>disoriented and at times difficult to arouse</fact11>, the <fact12>left pupil is 6 mm and non-reactive to light</fact12>, and the <fact13>right pupil is 2 mm and reactive to light</fact13>. A <fact14>right-sided visual field defect</fact14> is appreciated on visual field testing. There is <fact15>1/5 strength on the right upper and lower extremity</fact15>; as well as <fact16>5/5 strength in the left upper and lower extremity</fact16>. A computerized tomography (CT) scan of the head is shown. Which of the following most likely explains this patient’s symptoms?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the patient's symptoms of being <fact11>disoriented and at times difficult to arouse</fact11>, having a <fact12>left pupil that is 6 mm and non-reactive to light</fact12>, and a <fact14>right-sided visual field defect</fact14>, along with <fact15>weakness on the right upper and lower extremity</fact15>, suggest a significant intracranial event. Given the history of <fact4>hypertension and atrial fibrillation</fact4> and the use of anticoagulation with <fact5>warfarin</fact5>, the patient is at high risk for intracranial hemorrhage. The presence of <fact12>anisocoria (unequal pupil sizes)</fact12> and a <fact14>visual field defect</fact14> indicates a possible mass effect causing herniation. Among the options, the most likely explanation for the patient's symptoms is herniation of the uncus, which can cause compression of the oculomotor nerve leading to pupillary dilation and can also affect visual pathways leading to field defects. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 37-year-old man with no significant past medical history is rear-ended in a motor vehicle accident. He reported significant neck pain to emergency responders, but otherwise denies weakness, numbness or tingling in his extremities. His vitals on presentation to the ED are HR 90, BP 140/80, RR 20, SpO2 98%. What is the most appropriate next step upon presentation to the emergency room?
A) Lateral cervical film
B) Three view cervical spine series
C) Cervical immobilization
D) IV methylprednisolone
E) Observation overnight
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>37-year-old man</fact1> with no significant past medical history is rear-ended in a <fact2>motor vehicle accident</fact2>. He reported significant <fact3>neck pain</fact3> to emergency responders, but otherwise denies <fact4>weakness, numbness or tingling in his extremities</fact4>. His vitals on presentation to the ED are <fact5>HR 90, BP 140/80, RR 20, SpO2 98%</fact5>. What is the most appropriate next step upon presentation to the emergency room?

Answer: 
Given the <fact1>37-year-old man's</fact1> involvement in a <fact2>motor vehicle accident</fact2> and his complaint of significant <fact3>neck pain</fact3>, the most critical concern is potential cervical spine injury. Despite the absence of <fact4>weakness, numbness or tingling in his extremities</fact4>, the mechanism of injury and the presence of <fact3>neck pain</fact3> necessitate caution. The patient's vitals, <fact5>HR 90, BP 140/80, RR 20, SpO2 98%</fact5>, are stable but do not rule out the possibility of cervical spine injury. The most appropriate next step is to ensure <fact6>cervical immobilization</fact6> to prevent any potential movement that could worsen an injury. This is a standard precautionary measure in trauma cases with suspected cervical spine injury until further evaluation can be conducted. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 68-year-old woman presents with left lower quadrant pain that worsens with defecation. She describes the pain as 'crampy'. She also says she has suffered from mild constipation for the past few years. The patient denies any recent weight change or urinary symptoms. Her last menstrual period was 16 years ago. Her body temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 133/87 mm Hg. On physical examination, tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant is present. The laboratory studies are presented as follows:
Hemoglobin 13.2 mg/dL
Hematocrit 48%
Leukocyte count 16,000/mm³
Neutrophils 89%
Bands 5%
Eosinophils 0%
Basophils 0%
Lymphocytes 11%
Monocytes 0%
Platelet count 380,000/mm³
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Diverticulitis
B) Hypothyroidism
C) Adenocarcinoma of the colon
D) Chronic inflammatory bowel disease
E) Irritable bowel syndrome
answer:

She also says she has suffered from <fact5>mild constipation</fact5> for the past few years. The patient denies any recent <fact6>weight change</fact6> or <fact7>urinary symptoms</fact7>. Her last <fact8>menstrual period</fact8> was 16 years ago. Her <fact9>body temperature</fact9> is 37.8°C (100.0°F), <fact10>pulse</fact10> is 102/min, <fact11>respiratory rate</fact11> is 16/min, and <fact12>blood pressure</fact12> is 133/87 mm Hg. On physical examination, <fact13>tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant</fact13> is present. The laboratory studies are presented as follows:
<fact14>Hemoglobin 13.2 mg/dL</fact14>
<fact15>Hematocrit 48%</fact15>
<fact16>Leukocyte count 16,000/mm³</fact16>
<fact17>Neutrophils 89%</fact17>
<fact18>Bands 5%</fact18>
<fact19>Eosinophils 0%</fact19>
<fact20>Basophils 0%</fact20>
<fact21>Lymphocytes 11%</fact21>
<fact22>Monocytes 0%</fact22>
<fact23>Platelet count 380,000/mm³</fact23>
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer:
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>left lower quadrant pain</fact2> that worsens with <fact3>defecation</fact3> and is described as '<fact4>crampy</fact4>', along with a history of <fact5>mild constipation</fact5>, the clinical presentation is suggestive of diverticulitis. The patient's <fact9>body temperature</fact9> of 37.8°C (100.0°F) and elevated <fact10>pulse</fact10> of 102/min indicate an infectious or inflammatory process. The presence of <fact13>tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant</fact13> further supports this diagnosis. Laboratory results show an elevated <fact16>leukocyte count of 16,000/mm³</fact16> with a predominance of <fact17>neutrophils at 89%</fact17>, indicating a bacterial infection. Given these findings, the most likely diagnosis is diverticulitis. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health examination. She feels well but asks for advice about smoking cessation. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years. She has tried to quit several times without success. During the previous attempts, she has been extremely nervous and also gained weight. She has also tried nicotine lozenges but stopped taking them because of severe headaches and insomnia. She has bulimia nervosa. She takes no medications. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Diazepam
B) Nicotine patch
C) Varenicline
D) Motivational interviewing
E) Fluoxetine
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>22-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for a routine health examination. She feels well but asks for advice about <fact2>smoking cessation</fact2>. She has smoked <fact3>one pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years</fact3>. She has tried to quit several times without success. During the previous attempts, she has been extremely <fact4>nervous</fact4> and also gained <fact5>weight</fact5>. She has also tried <fact6>nicotine lozenges</fact6> but stopped taking them because of severe <fact7>headaches</fact7> and <fact8>insomnia</fact8>. She has <fact9>bulimia nervosa</fact9>. She takes no medications. She is <fact10>168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall</fact10> and weighs <fact11>68 kg (150 lb)</fact11>; <fact12>BMI is 24 kg/m2</fact12>. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's history of <fact9>bulimia nervosa</fact9> and previous unsuccessful attempts at <fact2>smoking cessation</fact2> due to <fact4>nervousness</fact4> and <fact5>weight gain</fact5>, along with adverse reactions to <fact6>nicotine lozenges</fact6> such as <fact7>headaches</fact7> and <fact8>insomnia</fact8>, a non-pharmacological approach may be more suitable. Among the options provided, <fact13>motivational interviewing</fact13> is a technique that can help individuals resolve ambivalence and mobilize their intrinsic motivation to change their behavior, which could be particularly beneficial for someone with a complex history like this patient. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is {D}.

question:
A 43-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after his son found him vomiting bright red blood. He is visibly intoxicated, and hospital records indicate a long history of alcohol substance abuse treated with antabuse (disulfiram). Vital signs include T 98.4, HR 89, BP 154/92, and RR 20. EGD is notable for mild esophagitis, and a longitudinal esophageal tear at the gastroesophageal junction, with no active bleeding. What is the next best course of action?
A) Cyanoacrylate injection and ligation with banding, IV fluid hydration, and NPO
B) Conservative management with IV fluid hydration and observation
C) Barium swallow to characterize the depth of mucosal involvement
D) Esophageal manometry and impedance studies
E) Calcium channel blockage and Botox injection of the lower esophageal sphincter
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>43-year-old male</fact1> is brought to the emergency department after his son found him <fact2>vomiting bright red blood</fact2>. He is visibly <fact3>intoxicated</fact3>, and hospital records indicate a long history of <fact4>alcohol substance abuse</fact4> treated with <fact5>antabuse (disulfiram)</fact5>. Vital signs include <fact6>T 98.4, HR 89, BP 154/92, and RR 20</fact6>. <fact7>EGD</fact7> is notable for <fact8>mild esophagitis</fact8>, and a <fact9>longitudinal esophageal tear at the gastroesophageal junction</fact9>, with <fact10>no active bleeding</fact10>. What is the next best course of action?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>vomiting bright red blood</fact2> and the findings of <fact8>mild esophagitis</fact8> and a <fact9>longitudinal esophageal tear at the gastroesophageal junction</fact9> on <fact7>EGD</fact7>, the most likely diagnosis is a Mallory-Weiss tear. Given that there is <fact10>no active bleeding</fact10>, the next best course of action is conservative management with IV fluid hydration and observation. This approach is appropriate for managing a Mallory-Weiss tear without active bleeding, especially in a patient with a history of <fact4>alcohol substance abuse</fact4> who is <fact3>intoxicated</fact3>. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A four-day-old neonate is brought to the pediatrician with vaginal discharge for the last two days. Her mother is concerned about the blood-tinged discharge but states that her daughter has been feeding and voiding well. The neonate was delivered at 39 weeks gestation by an uncomplicated vaginal delivery, and she and her mother were discharged home after two days. The prenatal course was complicated by chlamydia in the mother during the first trimester, for which she and the partner were both treated with a negative test of cure.
